p: Flours are physically characterized as fine powders obtained from the cereal grinding or starch present in food. Among the most common are wheat, corn, sorghum, rye, and oat flour. It is considered one of the main foods in the human diet [ 222]. In recent years, the worldâ€™s flour production has been characterized by its fortification by adding compounds and vitamins, supplementing the required daily nutritional balance [ 223]. The seeds, peels, and fruit pomace generated in the processing of food products present nutritional and sensory components, which are of great interest for preparing functional foods, thus reducing the addition of components in flours to obtain food products [ 224]. Consequently, studies have been carried out for the partial substitution of wheat, oat, and cornflour for peel, seed, and fruit pomace flour to prepare functional foods ( Table 13), which have shown a favorable impact on the products obtained, increasing the nutritional content and antioxidant activity (due to the increase in phenolic content), without altering the physical and organoleptic properties.
